The glaring insconsistency to have his chain of the French government is at once appa- rent on its force. The Indepen- ence of the Republic of Liberia

Liberia was recognized by France by Treaty in the past 1864. The State of Maryland in Liberia has acquired the territory now claimed by France in 1846 or thereabouts, and was with all hher territo- ries, waters, debts and dues admitted as an integral pension of this Republic, in 1867.

No obligations were raised by any European Power to the claim of the State of Maryland in Liberia to these territories, neither was any objection made "to Liber- ria's assuming jurisdiction over these territories as a part of the state of Mary- land in Liberia when it was incorporated into the Republic of Liberia, which facts were made public to the world at the time.
Of it true that the French government obtain- ed from the Chiefs of govern
and Little Beriby cession of these territories in the year 1868, the cession was certainly invalidated by the titles of the Republic of Liberia to the territories and question.

Again the alleged claim of Francae to the said Territories if such exists, has never been published to the world, Liberia having been allowed, before during, and after the year 1868, to exercise undisputed control over the whole exact line from Cape Calmas to the San Pedro River.

Of this new doctrine of France is permitted to obtain with respect to Liberia, the existence of the Republic cannot be guaranteed for a single day, but is in great longer of being extinguished at any moment, by an Power having a desire for territorial agrandisement
on the Coast of the African con- tinent, and who might obtain seeds of cession dating long after those granted to the American Colonization Society and this govern- ment.

The Papers relation to the Cession of the Beriby territories to the State of Maryland in Liberia may be ob- tained of the Honorable John B. Lastrabr, President of the Ameri- can Colonization Society, Wash- ington D.C. who was one of the founders of the sate of Mary- land in Liberia.

In the despatches (copies en- closed from Consul General Carrance to President Johnson, referring to the recent correspondence between the French government and himslef relation to the- Armoux and Dumont affairs, M. de Fryermet seems to be extremely irritated at what he is pleased to term the interference of the United States in the Affairs of the independent State of

Liberia, and demands the right of the United States to interference in these Affairs. He goes so far as to assert that if these inter- ferences be continued, it will cause friendly relations be broken off, not between France and the United States which he is pleased to term an "in- terferer," but with teh Republic of Liberia, the government of which has even studiously en- deavored to avoid giving grands of offence or complaint to the French government.
We recognize to right-of the United States to interfere in our affairs for the reasons assigned by you in your despatch No. 67, to Minister McIan Paris, of being "Liberia's next best friend."
France having no colonies or territories adjacent or contiguous to Liberia, and then being no commercial intercourse either way, no questions of boudnary, ill treatment of French citizens
or any other questions over at issue betwenn us.
You are doubtless aware that France has for many years been secretly endeavoring to gain a foothold or to active- ly intervene for the purpose of dismembering the Republic.

Between the years 1860-70,, under the Second Empire, an attempt was made to destroy the Republic, by laying claim to Grand Bassa, a point some 50 or 60 miles south of Monrovia. Also an alternate agreement originating with French government was made with another Power to dismember the Repub- lic, -one Power annexing down to Cape Mount on the North, the French from Cape Palmas southwards.
